citation.article-title: Thermococcus coalescens sp. nov., a cell-fusing hyperthermophilic archaeon from Suiyo Seamount
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Thermococcus coalescens sp. nov.
Thermococcus coalescens [co.a.les′cens. L. part. adj. coalescens (from L. v. coalesco) coalescing, indicating that the cells coalesce].
Cells are irregular cocci, variable in size (0·5–5·0 μm in diameter depending on the level of cell fusion) and motile by a polar tuft of flagella.
Sulfur is not necessary for growth but significantly enhances growth.
With sulfur, cells grow in the range of 57–90 °C (optimum 87 °C), pH 5·2–8·7 (optimum, pH 6·5) and 1·5–4·5 % NaCl (optimum 2·5 %).
The highest apparent growth rate is 2·5 h−1.
Grows on yeast extract and tryptone.
Core lipids consist of archaeol, trialkyl-caldarchaeol and caldarchaeol, without cyclopentane ring.
The DNA G+C content is 53·9 mol%.

The type strain, TS1T (=JCM 12540T=DSM 16538T), was isolated from hot water emitted from a casing pipe driven into a hydrothermal site at Suiyo Seamount (28° 34′ 17″ N 140° 38′ 38″ E) at a depth of 1380 m.
